thread.title_full: Justin Bieber or Joy Division? What your musical tastes say about you.

author: Peter Munro
title: Justin Bieber or Joy Division? What your musical tastes say about you.
text:
Those who favour pop songs such as Taylor Swift's Wildest Dreams, are often self-assured and annoying to be around. 
Personality influences our response to sad music In the great karaoke contest of life, some days will be Bobby McFerrins, others will be Morrisseys. Whether your musical tastes tend towards singing in the rain or sheltering under your doona, alone, on a Saturday night, while lip-syncing to Leonard Cohen, the songs you choose say something about you.
Playing sad songs by The Smiths, Sinead O'Connor, The Cure or Joy Division suggests to me that you are struggling with singledom/substance abuse/childhood trauma/traffic jams/crippling insecurities/hair loss/panda eyes/the painful death of everyone you ever loved/Mondays.
If you love sad songs by the likes of Sinead O'Connor you could be suffering from childhood trauma, substance abuse or singledom. Photo: Supplied 
Playing pop songs by Pharrell Williams, Wham!, Tiny Tim, Taylor Swift or Daft Punk suggests you are a dancer/big hat wearer/ukulele fancier/rather self-assured and annoying to be around.
Advertisement Playing any song by Justin Bieber suggests you are very young or old enough to know better.
A rather more scientific study by Curtin University of musical preferences and personality found people with high self-esteem typically enjoy listening to the blues, jazz, classical music, opera and rap. Heavy metal fans tend to be more insecure and, likely, hard of hearing. Creative people prefer indie music. Hard workers dig country music and pop. Lazy people like funk.
Social butterflies tend to play dance music, while nervous people prefer chart pop songs â€“ perhaps taking comfort within a crowd. The survey of 35,618 people found musical tastes also tend to reveal someone's social set, with fans of jazz, opera and classical music typically enjoying high incomes. Such people are also more likely to be conservative voters. Their preference for wearing turtleneck sweaters and berets is assumed.
Being a practical man, I prefer songs that contain clear guides for day-to-day life, such as You're The Reason Our Kids Are Ugly or Meatloaf's Objects In The Rear View Mirror May Appear Closer Than They Are. 
But it's the laments that tend to reveal most about who we are and why we are weeping all the time. A Rolling Stone poll in 2013 found the most miserable songs of all time include I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry , Cat's In The Cradle and Tears In Heaven . "Everybody hurts sometimes," sang R.E.M. Anyone who has had to listen to anything by Ariana Grande could only agree.
